awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coupling Archaeological shell and novel isotope approaches to reconstruct impact of nearshore productivity change
awd_abstract_narration:
A central issue in archaeology is understanding how people were influenced by past environmental change and how they, in turn, actively shaped ecosystems and organisms around them. To explore those questions, some archaeologists have attempted to understand the origins of hierarchical sociopolitical systems among the densely populated coastal regions. Drawing on the analysis of artifacts, village structure, human subsistence, and high-precision climate records, archaeologists have rigorously debated the impact of hypothesized declines in marine productivity and extended El Niño conditions vs. extended drought. Even in contexts with exceptionally high-resolution marine climate records in the world, interpreting past climatic data can be incredibly challenging where surface oceanography across the region is highly variable. This project provides training opportunities for several undergraduate and graduate students, especially members of historically under-represented groups and Indigenous communities, and will support a wide variety of outreach activities.

This research seeks to understand when and why cultural complexity arose along one such region and any links it may have to past changes in climate. To address these issues, the researchers draw on the analysis of novel molecular/isotopes (compound-specific isotopes of amino acids or CSI-AA) in shells obtained from archaeological sites. CSI-AA is well preserved in archaeological shell and can directly record climate-linked shifts in local oceanography, including nutrient sources, baseline primary production, trophic structure, and algal community composition. This analysis offers a new, highly localized source of past climate variation and environmental productivity to help address the central research questions. This project is the first systematic archeological application of CSI-AA analyses addressing broad social, political, and cultural developments in California and will have far reaching implications for archaeological research on past environmental change around the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For 13,000 years, Indigenous peoples of southern California thrived by relying on coastal and marine resources and adapting to both short-term fluctuations and long-term environmental changes in marine productivity. By integrating paleoenvironmental and archaeological data from California’s northern Channel Islands, we produced one of the most detailed and localized records of marine environmental change in the Americas. We used a novel approach, applying new geochemical analyses to intertidal marine shellfish samples collected from archaeological sites spanning the last 3000 years, as well as modern shellfish for comparison. Specifically, we measured isotope ratios in amino acids preserved in archaeological shell—well preserved remains of proteins that the past animals used to build their shells. The patterns observed in these amino acid measurements can tell us about past ocean conditions by creating a record of nutrient sources and levels. Our work substantially expands the understanding of these new approaches, and demonstrates that they can be used for reconstructing marine productivity over many millennia.

Our research has produced several important findings, some of which were foundational to testing our initial hypothesis. First, we performed a comparative study between two time periods (Late Holocene and Late Pleistocene) to assess ecosystem structure and to demonstrate the usefulness of archaeological data to create baseline ecological assessments of the past. To do this, we synthesized archaeological shellfish and other animal remains from archaeological sites throughout the northern Channel Islands from 3000 years ago to the present. We also analyzed fossil shellfish data from ~80,000 and 120,000 years ago, documenting marine ecosystems prior to the arrival of people. These data showed some continuity and differences between deep time Channel Island intertidal ecosystems and those of the past 3000 years and present day. 

Second, we tested the preservation of geochemical signals in archaeological shell by comparing isotope signals in modern and archaeological (150-6000 years ago) California mussel shells. We found that, while some shells had undergone geochemical alteration, the underlying proxies were still preserved. Finally, we performed a modern baseline study to determine the physical and biogeochemical drivers in our isotope measurements. We found that carbon and nitrogen isotope measurements in marine shellfish in southern California are recording changes in primary productivity and shifts in water masses, and that environmental perturbations such as El Niño/La Niña cycles are reflected in the isotope signatures of marine shellfish. These studies built a new foundation for geochemical analyses of carbon and nitrogen isotopes in archaeological and modern marine shellfish. This is important because we can now reconstruct changes in local marine productivity through time on the Channel Islands.

The new records we developed demonstrate that significant changes have occurred in nearshore marine productivity, particularly during the past 1500 years. Notably the period between about 1000-700 years ago, corresponding to the Medieval Climatic Anomaly, exhibited substantially reduced nutrient availability and lower marine productivity. Prior to this, the preceding 500 years were highly variable, with conditions later becoming cooler and more productive after about 700 years ago. The period of reduced productivity during portions of the Medieval Climatic Anomaly coincided with substantial shifts in Native American social organization and a transition from people relying on shellfish to focusing primarily on finfish. Our research demonstrates that local fluctuations in marine productivity were likely key drivers of some of these cultural developments, which may have varied at different locations across the northern Channel Islands. Ultimately, these findings help evaluate changes in local marine ecosystems observed in the present day and can help scientists contextualize and understand likely future environmental changes in one of the most productive marine ecosystems and important fishery regions on the West Coast. These findings have been reported in published academic journal articles, public talks, and other outreach, and additional publications are in progress.
